[[File:DampedSine.png|thumb|350px|<math>y(t) = e^{- t} \cdot \cos(2 \pi t)</math>]]
A '''damped sine wave''' is a [[Sine wave|sinusoidal function]] whose amplitude approaches zero as time increases.<ref>Douglas C. Giancoli (2000). [''Physics for Scientists and Engineers with Modern Physics (3rd Edition)'']. Prentice Hall. {{ISBN|0-13-021517-1}}</ref>
Damped sine waves are commonly seen in [[science]] and [[engineering]], wherever a [[harmonic oscillator]] is losing [[energy]] faster than it is being supplied.
== Definition == Sine waves describe many oscillating phenomena. When the wave is damped, each successive peak decreases as time goes on.
A true sine wave starting at time = 0 begins at the origin (amplitude = 0). A cosine wave begins at its maximum value due to its phase difference from the sinewave. In practice a given waveform may be of intermediate phase, having both sine and cosine components. The term "damped sine wave" describes all such damped waveforms, whatever their initial phase value.
The most common form of damping, and that usually assumed, is exponential damping, in which the outer envelope of the successive peaks is an exponential decay curve.
==Equations== The general equation for an exponentially damped sinusoid may be represented as:
:<math>y(t) = A \cdot e^{-\lambda t} \cdot (\cos(\omega t + \phi) + \sin(\omega t + \phi))</math> where: :<math>y(t)</math> is the instantaneous amplitude at time ''t'' :<math>A</math> is the initial amplitude of the envelope. :<math>\lambda</math> is the decay constant, in the reciprocal of the time units of the X axis. :<math>\phi</math> is the phase angle at some arbitrary point. :<math>\omega</math> is the [[Angular frequency]].
which can be simplified to :<math>y(t) = A \cdot e^{-\lambda t} \cdot (\cos(\omega t + \phi))</math>
Where: :<math>\phi</math> is the phase angle at ''t'' = 0.
Other important parameters include: :Period <math>\tau</math>, the time it takes for a single cycle, in units of time ''t''. It is the reciprocal of frequency (see below), i.e. <math>f^{-1}</math>. :Frequency <math>f</math>. is the number of cycles per time unit, and is equal to <math> \omega /(2 \pi) </math>. It is the reciprocal of period, i.e. <math>\tau^{-1}</math>. and is expressed in inverse time units <math>t^{-1}</math>. :[[Half-life]] is the time it takes for the exponential amplitude envelope to decrease by a factor of 2. It is equal to <math>\ln(2)/\lambda</math> which is approximately <math>0.693/\lambda</math>. :Wavelength of a travelling wave is the distance between adjacent peaks and varies according to the speed of the wave's travel.
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Audio system measurements]] * [[Critically damped]] * [[Damping ratio]] * [[Damping factor]] * [[Electromagnetic pulse]] * [[Harmonic oscillator]] * [[Impulse excitation technique]] * [[Oscillator]] * [[Particle damping]] * [[Resonance]] * [[RLC circuit]] * [[Simple harmonic motion]] * [[Thermoelastic damping]] * [[Thrust damping]] * [[Tuned mass damper]] * [[Vehicle suspension]] * [[Vibration]] * [[Vibration control]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Waves]]

{{Infobox manuscript | name = Derveni papyrus | location = [[Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki]] | image = Derveni-papyrus.jpg | width = | caption = Some fragments of the Derveni papyrus | Also known as = | Type = Papyrus roll | Date = 340 BC, from an end 5th century BC original | Place of origin = Macedon | Language(s) = Ancient Greek, mixed dialects | Scribe(s) = | Author(s) = | Compiled by = | Illuminated by = | Patron = | Dedicated to = | Material = Papyrus | Size = 266 fragments | Format = 26 columns | Condition = Fragmentary, charred from funeral pyre | Script = | Contents = Commentary on a hexameter poem ascribed to Orpheus | Illumination(s) = | Additions = | Exemplar(s) = | Previously kept = | Discovered = 1962 | Accession = | Other = | below = }} The '''Derveni papyrus''' is an [[Ancient Macedonians|ancient Macedonian]] [[papyrus]] roll that was found in 1962. It is a philosophical treatise that is an allegorical commentary on an [[Orphic]] poem, a [[theogony]] concerning the birth of the gods, produced in the circle of the philosopher [[Anaxagoras]]. It was composed near the end of the 5th century BC,{{cite web | title=The Derveni Papyrus: An Interdisciplinary Research Project | work=Harvard University, Center for Hellenic Studies | url=http://chs.harvard.edu/CHS/article/display/5418}} and "in the fields of Greek religion, the sophistic movement, early philosophy, and the origins of literary criticism it is unquestionably the most important textual discovery of the 20th century."Richard Janko, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/20191519 "The Derveni Papyrus: An Interim Text"], ''Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik, 141 (2002), p. 1 The roll itself dates to around 340 BC, during the reign of [[Philip II of Macedon]], making it Europe's oldest surviving [[manuscript]].{{cite news | title=Ancient scroll may yield religious secrets | agency=Associated Press | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/13081639/ | accessdate=1 June 2006}}{{cite web|title=THE PAPYRUS OF DERVENI |work=[[Hellenic Ministry of Culture]] |url=http://www.culture.gr/2/21/215/21505/215052/e21505206.html |accessdate=1 June 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060428200149/http://www.culture.gr/2/21/215/21505/215052/e21505206.html |archivedate=28 April 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} While interim editions and translations were published over the subsequent years, the manuscript as a whole was finally published in 2006. ==Discovery== [[File:The Derveni Papyrus.jpg|thumb|250px|left|The Derveni papyrus – [[Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki]]]] The roll was found on 15 January 1962 at a site in [[Derveni, Thessaloniki|Derveni]], [[Macedonia (Greece)|Macedonia]], northern [[Greece]], on the road from [[Thessaloniki]] to [[Kavala]]. The site is a nobleman's grave in a [[necropolis]] that was part of a rich cemetery belonging to the ancient city of [[Lete (Mygdonia)|Lete]].{{cite book|last=Betegh|first=Gábor|title=The Derveni Papyrus: Cosmology, Theology and Interpretation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5HaKQFeYSBEC&pg=PA56|accessdate=14 January 2012|date=19 November 2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-04739-5|page=56}} It is the oldest surviving manuscript in the Western tradition and one of the very few surviving papyri, and probably the oldest literary papyrus, found in Greece. The archaeologists Petros Themelis and Maria Siganidou recovered the top parts of the charred papyrus scroll and fragments from ashes atop the slabs of the tomb; the bottom parts had burned away in the funeral pyre. The scroll was carefully unrolled and the fragments joined together, thus forming 26 columns of text. It survived in the humid Greek soil, which is unfavorable to the conservation of papyri, because it was [[Carbonization|carbonized]] (hence dried) in the nobleman’s funeral pyre.{{cite book|last=Betegh|first=Gábor|title=The Derveni Papyrus: Cosmology, Theology and Interpretation|date=2004|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=9780521801089|page=59}} However, this has made it extremely difficult to read, since the ink is black and the background is black too; in addition, it survives in the form of 266 fragments, which are conserved under glass in descending order of size, and has had to be painstakingly reconstructed. Many smaller fragments are still not placed. The papyrus is kept in the [[Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki]]. ==Content== The main part of the text is a commentary on a [[hexameter]] poem ascribed to [[Orpheus]], which was used in the mystery cult of [[Dionysus]] by the 'Orphic initiators'. Fragments of the poem are quoted, followed by interpretations by the main author of the text, who tries to show that the poem does not mean what it literally says. The poem begins with the words "Close the doors, you uninitiated", a famous admonition to secrecy, also quoted by [[Plato]]. The interpreter claims that this shows that Orpheus wrote his poem as an allegory. The theogony described in the poem has [[Nyx]] (Night) give birth to Heaven ([[Uranus (mythology)|Uranus]]), who becomes the first king. [[Cronus]] follows and takes the kingship from Uranus, but he is likewise succeeded by [[Zeus]], whose power over the whole universe is celebrated. Zeus gains his power by hearing oracles from the sanctuary of Night, who tells him "all the oracles which afterwards he was to put into effect."Bowersock, G. W. ''[http://www.tnr.com/doc.mhtml?i=20050606&s=bowersock060605&c=2 Tangled Roots]''. From ''The New Republic Online'' 8 June 2005. Retrieved 6 June 2006. At the end of the text Zeus rapes his mother [[Rhea (mythology)|Rhea]], which, in the Orphic theogony, will lead to the birth of [[Demeter]]. Zeus would then have raped Demeter, who would then have given birth of [[Persephone]], who then married Dionysus. However, this part of the story must have continued in a second roll which is now lost. The interpreter of the poem argues that Orpheus did not intend any of these stories in a literal sense, but they are allegorical in nature. {{quote|This poem is strange and riddling to people, though [Orpheus] did not intend to tell contentious riddles but rather great things in riddles. In fact he is speaking mystically, and from the very first word all the way to the last. As he also makes clear in the well recognized verse: for, having ordered them to "put doors to their ears," he says that he is not legislating for the many [but addressing himself to those] who are pure in hearing … and in the following verse …{{cite book |last1=Bierl |first1=Anton |title=‘Riddles over Riddles’: ‘Mysterious’ and ‘Symbolic’ (Inter)textual Strategies. The Problem of Language in the Derveni Papyrus |date=2014 |publisher=University of Basel |location=978-0-674-72676-5}}}} The first surviving columns of the text are less well preserved, but talk about occult ritual practices, including sacrifices to the [[Erinyes]] (Furies), how to remove [[Daemon (classical mythology)|daimones]] that become a problem, and the beliefs of the [[magi]]. They include a quotation of the philosopher [[Heraclitus]]. Their reconstruction is extremely controversial, since even the order of fragments is disputed. Two different reconstructions have recently been offered, that by Valeria Piano{{Cite journal|last=Piano|first=Valeria|year=2016|title=P.Derveni III-VI: una reconsiderazione del testo|url=|journal=Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik|volume=197|pages=5–16|via=}}{{Cite book|title=Il Papiro di Derveni tra religione e filosofia|last=Piano|first=Valeria|publisher=Leo S. Olschki|year=2016|isbn=978-88-222-6477-0|location=Florence|pages=}} and that by Richard Janko, who says that he has found that these columns also include a quotation of the philosopher [[Parmenides]].{{Cite journal|last=Janko|first=Richard|year=2016|title=Parmenides in the Derveni Papyrus|url=|journal=Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik|volume=200|pages=3–23|via=}} ==Recent reading== The text was not officially published for forty-four years after its discovery (though three partial editions were published). A team of experts was assembled in autumn 2005 led by A. L. Pierris of the Institute for Philosophical studies and [[Dirk Obbink]], director of the [[Oxyrhynchus Papyri]] project at the University of Oxford, with the help of modern multispectral imaging techniques by [[Roger Macfarlane]] and Gene Ware of [[Brigham Young University]] to attempt a better approach to the edition of a difficult text. However, nothing appears to have been published as a result of that initiative, and the photographs are not available to scholars or the Museum. Meanwhile, the papyrus was finally published by a team of scholars from [[Thessaloniki]] (Tsantsanoglou et al., below), which provides a complete text of the papyrus based on autopsy of the fragments, with photographs and translation. More work clearly remained to be done (see Janko 2006, below). Subsequent progress has been made in reading the papyrus by Valeria Piano and Richard Janko, who has developed a new method for taking digital microphotographs of the papyrus, which permits some of its most difficult passages to be read for the first time.{{cite web|url=https://classicalstudies.org/annual-meeting/146/abstract/new-readings-derveni-papyrus|title=New readings in the Derveni Papyrus|last=|first=|date=|website=|dead-url=|access-date=29 March 2017}} Examples of these images are now published. A version of Janko's new text is available in the recent edition by Mirjam Kotwick, and a new edition in English is in preparation.{{cite web|url=https://www.acls.org/news/2-23-2016/|title=Nine Teams of Scholars Awarded 2016 ACLS Collaborative Research Fellowships|last=|first=|date=|website=|dead-url=|access-date=29 March 2017}} A complete digital edition of the papyrus using the new technique is a major ''desideratum''. ==Style of writing== The text of the papyrus contains a mix of dialects. It is mainly a mixture of [[Attic Greek|Attic]] and [[Ionic Greek|Ionic]] Greek; however it contains a few [[Doric Greek|Doric]] forms. Sometimes the same word appears in different dialectal forms e.g. cμικρό-, μικρό; ὄντα, ἐόντα; νιν for μιν etc.For a full list, see Janko (1997) 62–3 == Oldest 'book' of Europe – UNESCO Memory of The World Register == [[File:Derveni Papyrus - Fragments on display in the Archaelogical Museum of Thessaloniki.jpg|thumb|right|The Derveni papyrus fragments as displayed in the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki, along with the UNESCO dedication in the middle of the panel]] On 12 December 2015, the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki held the official event to celebrate the registration of the Derveni Papyrus in the UNESCO [[Memory of the World Register – Europe and North America|Memory of the World Register]]. According to UNESCO
"The Derveni Papyrus is of immense importance not only for the study of Greek religion and philosophy, which is the basis for the western philosophical thought, but also because it serves as a proof of the early dating of the Orphic poems offering a distinctive version of [[Pre-Socratic philosophy|Presocratic philosophers]]. The text of the Papyrus, which is the first book of western tradition, has a global significance, since it reflects universal human values: the need to explain the world, the desire to belong to a human society with known rules and the agony to confront the end of life."{{cite web|title = The Derveni Papyrus: The oldest 'book' of Europe {{!}} United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|url = http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/flagship-project-activities/memory-of-the-world/register/full-list-of-registered-heritage/registered-heritage-page-8/the-derveni-papyrus-the-oldest-book-of-europe/|website = www.unesco.org|accessdate = 14 December 2015}}

''Il Papiro di Derveni tra religione e filosofia'' (Leo. S. Olschki Editore, Florence [series ''Studi e testi per il Corpus dei papiri filosofici greci e latini'', vol. 18]). {{ISBN|88-222-6477-0}}. * V. Piano, "P.Derveni III-VI: una riconsiderazione del testo", ''Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik'' 197, 2016, pp. 5–16. *[http://ccat.sas.upenn.edu/bmcr/2006/2006-10-29.html Richard Janko's Review of Tsantsanoglou, Parássoglou, & Kouremenos 2006];[http://ccat.sas.upenn.edu/bmcr/2006/2006-11-02.html Tsantsanoglou, Parássoglou, & Kouremenos' Response to Janko]; [http://ccat.sas.upenn.edu/bmcr/2006/2006-11-20.html Janko's Response]. ==External links== {{commonscat}} * [http://dp.chs.harvard.edu/index.php?col=0&ed=KPT The Derveni papyrus at ''The iMouseion Project''] {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} *[http://www.ideasroadshow.com/issues/richard-janko-2013-08-09 "The Derveni Papyrus - A conversation with Richard Janko"], ''Ideas Roadshow'', 2013 {{DEFAULTSORT:Derveni Papyrus}} [[Category:Greek manuscripts]] [[Category:Ancient Greek works]] [[Category:Greek religion texts]] [[Category:Religion in ancient Macedonia]] [[Category:Philip II of Macedon]] [[Category:Greek-language papyri]] [[Category:Orpheus]] [[Category:Papyrology]] [[Category:Archaeological discoveries in Greece]] [[Category:Memory of the World Register]] [[Category:1962 archaeological discoveries]]

In [[Greek mythology]], '''Drosera''' ([[Ancient Greek]]: Δροσερῇ) was a [[naiads|naiad]]. She was one of the three ancestors of the [[Tyre (Lebanon)|Tyrians]], along with [[Abarbarea (Naiad ancestor of Tyrians)|Abarbarea]] and [[Callirrhoe (Oceanid)|Callirrhoe]]. These nymphs were joined to sons of the soil [[Autochthon (ancient Greece)|(autochthonous]]) by the god [[Eros]] who was angered by their chastity.[http://topostext.org/work.php?work_id=529#15.312 Nonnus, ''Dionysiaca Book 40.535ff''.] Translated by William Henry Denham Rouse (1863-1950), from the Loeb Classical Library, Cambridge, Massachusetts, Harvard University Press, 1940 == Mythology == In [[Nonnus]]' ''[[Dionysiaca]]''. Abarbarea was mentioned in the following text:
''"'There, Lord Dionysos, I have told you of the soilbred race of the Earthborn, self born, [[Twelve Olympians|Olympian]], that you might know how the Tyrian breed of your ancestors sprang out of the earth. Now I will speak of the fountains. In the olden days they were chaste maidens primeval, but hot Eros was angered against their maiden girdles, and drawing a shaft of love he spoke thus to the marriage-hating nymphs: ' Naiad Abarbarea, so fond of your maidenhood, you too receive this shaft, which all nature has felt. Here I will build Callirhoe's bridechamber, here I will sing '''Drosera's''' wedding hymn ... and from his [i.e. Eros] backbent bow let fly three shots. Then in that watery bower he joined in love sons of the soil to the Naiads, and sowed the divine race of your family.'"''
==References== [[Category:Naiads]] [[Category:Women in Greek mythology]] [[Category:Mythological Greek characters]] {{Greek-myth-stub}}

page.title: Energy switching services in the UK

revision.comment: Business Advisory Service is now owned by Smarter Business
revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=March 2009}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} '''Energy switching services''' are companies that have come to exist since the EU began deregulating the gas and electricity markets, to open them to competition, in 1996.<ref>UK energy markets deregulated in 1996. Article retrieved 4 October 2013 https://www.theenergyshop.com/HomeEnergy/advice-guides-deregulationHistory#.Uk6mZ00xhkg</ref> Progress has been uneven across member countries, but in the UK there is now open competition among suppliers. Pricing structures and special offers are often complicated enough that it's not obvious which supplier and tariff will be best value for a consumer. This has provided an opportunity for specialist price comparison services. These are chiefly offered by companies who will manage a change to a different supplier and tariff, as well as advising on the best one. These companies primarily operate over the Web, although some also offer a telephone service.
==Regulation== Energy switching companies usually operate on a commission model, where they are paid a flat fee by a supplier for each customer that they persuade to switch. This has been the cause of some controversy. In order to ensure that advice remains impartial, [[energywatch]], the UK gas and electricity watchdog, operates a voluntary code of conduct. To be accredited under the code, switching companies must satisfy Energywatch that:
# They are independent of gas and electricity suppliers, do not accept advertisements, and state where they receive commission # They include [[like for like]] price comparisons for all currently available tariffs for all licensed suppliers (for gas, electricity and dual fuel) # They run their own website and use their own tariff database and calculator # The payment methods offered include standard credit by cash/cheque, monthly and quarterly direct debit, and prepayment meter # They must list prices from no fewer than five of the cheapest suppliers, and the prices must include [[VAT]] # They provide, or direct customers towards, information on quality of service issues and energy efficiency programmes # They provide accurate price comparisons and state when prices were last updated.
==See also== * [[Price comparison service]] * [[uSwitch]]
== References and external links == {{reflist}} * {{cite web|url= http://www.energywatch.org.uk/uploads/confidence_code.pdf |title=Complete Energywatch code of conduct }} {{small|(257 [[Kibibyte|KiB]])}} * [http://www.energywatch.org.uk/help_and_advice/saving_money/price_comparison_services/index.asp Price comparison services], ''[[energywatch]]'' * [http://www.businessadvisoryservice.co.uk Gas and electricity price comparison services], ''[[Business Advisory Service]] - now [https://smarterbusiness.co.uk/ Smarter Business]'' {{Energy in the United Kingdom|sources}}
[[Category:Energy in the United Kingdom]]

page.title: Indiana University School of Public Health-Bloomington

revision.text:
{{coord|39.17218|-86.51843|display=title}} {{Infobox university |name = Indiana University
School of Public Health-Bloomington |image = IU_School_of_Public_Health-Bloomington_Logo_TRNS.png |image_size = 230px |type = [[Public university|Public]] [[school of public health]] |motto = Public Health Reimagined |established = 2012 |dean = David Allison |city = [[Bloomington, Indiana|Bloomington]] |state = [[Indiana]] |country = U.S. |students = 2,790 (2015-2016). |undergrad = 2,377 (2015-2016). |postgrad = 413 (2015-2016). |parent = [[Indiana University]] |campus = Small City |website = {{url|publichealth.indiana.edu}} }} [[File:Indiana University School of Public Health-Bloomington.png|alt= Indiana University School of Public Health-Bloomington|thumb|Indiana University School of Public Health-Bloomington]] The '''IU School of Public Health-Bloomington''' is an undergraduate and graduate school at [[Indiana University Bloomington]]. Until 2012, it was the School of Health, Physical Education, and Recreation (HPER). Now, the School of Public Health on IU's Bloomington campus is the largest school of public health in the [[Big Ten Conference|Big 10]]. With 2,790 [[undergraduate]] and [[Postgraduate education|graduate]] students, it offers 34 different degrees. It has five academic departments. The mission of the Indiana University School of Public Health-Bloomington is to promote health among individuals and communities in Indiana, the nation, and the world through integrated multidisciplinary approaches to research and creative activities, teaching, and community engagement.{{cite web|url=http://www.publichealth.indiana.edu/about/profile.shtml|title=Mission, Goals, and Objectives: About Us: School of Public Health: Indiana University Bloomington|publisher=}} == History == The precursor to the '''School of Public Health-Bloomington''', the School of Health, Physical Education, and Recreation, was founded in 1946. In 2012, the school became the School of Public Health-Bloomington.{{Cite web|url=http://newsinfo.iu.edu/news-archive/23199.html|title=IU School of Public Health-Bloomington formally named, celebrated: IU News Room: Indiana University|website=newsinfo.iu.edu|access-date=2016-05-10}} The school earned accreditation from the [[Council on Education for Public Health]] in 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://www.publichealth.indiana.edu/about/accreditation/|title=The newly named Indiana University School of Public Health-Bloomington, has a long, proud history of outstanding achievements across an array of academic fields related health, wellness, and disease-prevention.|website=www.publichealth.indiana.edu|access-date=2016-05-10}} It has the oldest Master of Public Health program, established in 1969, in the state of Indiana.{{Cite web|url=http://www.publichealth.indiana.edu/about/history.shtml|title=The newly named Indiana University School of Public Health-Bloomington, has a long, proud history of outstanding achievements across an array of academic fields related health, wellness, and disease-prevention.|website=www.publichealth.indiana.edu|access-date=2016-05-10}} A history book, titled "A Legacy Transformed", about the school's origins and transformation into the IU School of Public Health-Bloomington, was published in 2016.{{cite web|url=https://info.publichealth.indiana.edu/releases/iub/sph/2016/05/new_sph_history_book.shtml|title=New book details the history of the IU School of Public Health-Bloomington: News: School of Public Health: Indiana University Bloomington|publisher=}} == Curriculum == The school offers a variety of undergraduate and graduate degrees, all with various concentrations: === [[Bachelor of Science]] === * B.S. in Environmental Health * B.S. in Public Health * B.S. in Kinesiology * B.S. in Recreation * B.S. in Occupational Health and Safety === [[Master of Science]] === * M.S. in Applied Health Science * M.S. in Kinesiology * M.S. in Recreation * M.S. in Safety Management * Master of Public Health The [[Master of Public Health|Master of Public Health Program (MPH)]] offers eight degree fields of study: * Behavioral, Social and Community Health * Biostatistics * Environmental Health * Epidemiology * Family Health * Physical Activity * Professional Health Education * Public Health Administration === [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] === * Environmental Health * Epidemiology * Leisure Behavior * Human Performance * Health Behavior == Centers and institutes == === Centers === * Bradford Woods Outdoor and Leadership Center * Center for Research on Health Disparities * Center for Sexual Health Promotion * Center for Sport Policy and Conduct * Counsilman Center for the Science of Swimming * Indiana Prevention Resource Center * National Center on Accessibility * Study Design & Data Analysis Center * Rural Center for AIDS/STD Prevention * Wynn F. Updyke Center for Physical Activity === Institutes & working groups === * [[Eppley Institute for Parks and Public Lands]] * Institute for Research on Addictive Behaviors * Leisure Research Institute * Tobacco Control and Wellness Research Working Group === Laboratories === * Adapted Physical Education Lab * Applied Health Behavior Research Laboratory * Human Performance Lab * Industrial Hygiene Laboratory * Nutrition Science Laboratories * Oxidative Stress Environmental Analysis Core Laboratory * Underwater Science Lab === Affiliated programs === * Academic Diving Program * Dick Enberg Distance Learning Studio * Executive Development Program * Great Lakes Park Training Institute * Counsilman Center Indiana Swim Team (CCiST) * Institute for Outdoor Leadership and Education * Outdoor Pool * The President's Challenge * Royer Pool * Sports Medicine Facilities * Tennis Center * Tourism Research and Education Consortium (TREC) == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Indiana University]] [[Category:Schools of public health in the United States]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Indiana]] [[Category:Global health]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 2012]]

revision.comment: /* History */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: July of 1901 → July 1901 using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Keweenawite''' is a discredited mineral species. It was described as an [[arsenide]] of [[copper]], [[nickel]], and [[cobalt]] containing 39% to 54% copper, 9.7% to 20% nickel, and 0.9% cobalt.<ref name=WMRV4-5>[https://books.google.com/books?id=I5w3AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA514&lpg=PA514&dq=Mohawk+and+Traverse+Bay+Railroad&source=bl&ots=79AFqh7JDU&sig=QWPdy5R_0vVSH9y2S7T-LeblD_Q&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o43bUeDyCtiv4AOg3YHwBQ&ved=0CFYQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=keweenawite&f=false World Mines Register, Volumes 4-5]</ref> Keweenawite was discovered in July 1901, in the [[Mohawk Mine]], [[Keweenaw County]], [[Michigan]]. George A Koenig analyzed and named the copper ore.<ref name=WRMV2>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Sp83AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA22&dq=keweenawite&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YZfbUduZFIbkyQHr3YAw&ved=0CEEQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=keweenawite&f=false World Mines Register, Volume 2]</ref>
==History== Keweenawite was first discovered, in July 1901, located on the fifth level of the [[Mohawk Mine]] between Shaft No. 1 and Shaft No. 2. Fred Smith, mine superintendent, sent specimens to George A Koenig for analysis. Dr. Koenig deemed it to be a new mineral species and named it Keweenawite, after its discovery locality, Keweenaw County. <ref name=TAJOFV164>[https://books.google.com/books?id=-007AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA410&dq=keweenawite&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YZfbUduZFIbkyQHr3YAw&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=keweenawite&f=false The American journal of science, Volume 164]</ref>
However, a re-analysis of the material in 1971 found the keweenite to be a mixture of the copper and nickel arsenates: [[domeykite|α-domeykite]], [[niccolite]] and [[rammelsbergite]].<ref>Moore, Paul B.; ''Copper-Nickel Arsenides of the Mohawk No. 2 Mine, Mohawk, Keweenaw Co., Michigan,'' American Mineralogist, V. 56, July-August, 1971 [http://www.minsocam.org/ammin/AM56/AM56_1319.pdf PDF]</ref>
==See also== *[[Mohawkite]] - Another discredited mineral species discovered in the Mohawk mine and analysed by George A Koenig
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{wiktionary}} [[Category:Minerals]] [[Category:Rocks]] [[Category:Geology of Michigan]]
{{mineral-stub}}

==References== * {{aut|Platnick, Norman I.}} (2014): [http://research.amnh.org/iz/spiders/catalog/MICROSTIGMATIDAE.html The world spider catalog], version 14.5. ''American Museum of Natural History''. {{doi|10.5531/db.iz.0001}}

page.title: List of Roman dams and reservoirs

List of national parks in Malaysia

revision.text:
[[Malaysia]] has a number of [[national park]]s but most of them are ''de facto'' state parks.
This page provides the list of protected areas and pictures associated with the facilities and activities available in each area.
==Peninsular Malaysia== All parks and reserves in Peninsular Malaysia are under the jurisdiction of the [[Department of Wildlife and National Parks]] of Malaysia.
===National parks=== * [[Taman Negara|Taman Negara National Park]], established 1939 * [[Endau-Rompin National Park]], gazetted 1993 * [[Penang National Park]], declared 2003 * [[Mount Ophir|Gunung Ledang National Park]], gazetted 2005 * [[Taman Negara Johor Tanjung Piai]] * [[Taman Negara Johor Pulau Kukup]]
===State parks and reserves=== ;Johor * [[Hutan Lipur Sungai Bantang]] * [[Hutan Lipur Gunung Arong]] * [[Hutan Lipur Gunung Berlumut]]
;Kelantan * [[Gunung Stong State Park]]
;Pahang * [[Krau Wildlife Reserve]]
;Perak * [[Royal Belum State Park]] * [[Sungkai Sambar Deer and Pheasant Wildlife Reserve]]
;Perlis * [[Perlis State Park]] * Wang Pinang Reserve
;Selangor * [[Selangor Heritage Park]] * [[Bukit Cahaya Seri Alam]] * [[Sungai Dusun Wildlife Reserve]] * [[Templer's Park]]
==East Malaysia== {{Location map+|Borneo|float=right|width=450|caption=The national parks of Sarawak and Sabah|places= {{Location map~|Borneo|lat=1.72|long=110.47|label=<small>'''Bako'''</small>|position=top|mark=Green pog.svg}} {{Location map~|Borneo|lat=3.81|long=113.78|label=<small>'''Niah Caves'''</small>|position=left|mark=Green pog.svg}} {{Location map~|Borneo|lat=1.69|long=109.84|label=<small>'''Gunung Gading'''</small>|position=left|mark=Green pog.svg}} {{Location map~|Borneo|lat=3.95|long=114.78|label=<small>'''Gunung Mulu'''</small>|position=right|mark=Green pog.svg}} {{Location map~|Borneo|lat=1.13|long=111.88|label=<small>'''Batang Ai'''</small>|position=left|mark=Green pog.svg}} {{Location map~|Borneo|lat=6.00|long=115.85|label=<small>'''Tunku Abdul Rahman'''</small>|position=left|mark=Green pog.svg}} {{Location map~|Borneo|lat=5.58|long=116.08|label=<small>'''Crocker Range'''</small>|position=right|mark=Green pog.svg}} {{Location map~|Borneo|lat=6.15|long=116.65|label=<small>'''Kinabalu'''</small>|position=right|mark=Green pog.svg}} {{Location map~|Borneo|lat=4.6|long=118.7|label=<small>'''Tun Sakaran'''</small>|position=bottom|mark=Green pog.svg}} }}
===Sarawak=== National Parks and other conservation areas in Sarawak are under the governance of the Sarawak Forestry Corporation [https://www.sarawakforestry.com/] * [[Bako National Park]] * [[Gunung Mulu National Park]] * [[Niah National Park]] * [[Lambir Hills National Park]] * [[Miri-Sibuti Coral Reef National Park]] * [[Loagan Bunut National Park]] * [[Similajau National Park]] * [[Gunung Gading National Park]] * [[Kubah National Park]] * [[Batang Ai National Park]] * [[Tanjung Datu National Park]] * [[Talang Satang National Park]] * [[Bukit Tiban National Park]] * [[Maludam National Park]] * [[Rajang Mangroves National Park]] * [[Gunung Buda National Park]] * [[Pulong Tau National Park]] * [[Kuching Wetlands National Park]] * Wind Cave Reserve * Samunsam Wildlife Sanctuary * Stutung Reserve * Matang Wildlife Centre
===Sabah=== National or state parks in Sabah are managed by [[Sabah Parks]]. Other reserves or protected areas are under the governance of the Sabah Forestry Department and Sabah Foundation. * [[Crocker Range National Park|Crocker Range Park]] * [[Kinabalu National Park|Kinabalu Park]] * [[Pulau Tiga National Park|Pulau Tiga Park]] * [[Tawau Hills National Park|Tawau Hills Park]] * [[Tun Sakaran Marine Park]] * [[Tunku Abdul Rahman National Park|Tunku Abdul Rahman Park]] * [[Turtle Islands National Park|Turtle Islands Park]] * [[Sipadan Island Park]] * [[Tun Mustapha Marine Park]] * [[Kota Kinabalu Wetland Centre]] * Lok Kawi Wildlife Park * Padang Teratak Wetlands Area * Lower Kinabatangan - Segama Wetlands * Lower Kinabatangan Wildlife Sanctuary * Tabin Wildlife Reserve * Sepilok Orang Utan Rehabilitation Centre
==See also== * [[Department of Wildlife and National Parks]] * [[Protected areas of Johor]] * [[Malaysian Wildlife Law]] * [[Deforestation in Malaysia]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|National parks of Malaysia}} * [http://www.wildlife.gov.my Department of Wildlife and National Parks of Malaysia (PERHILITAN)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081006183249/http://johorparks.com.my/ Johor National Parks Corporation Website (JNPC)] * Travel Ideas for [https://web.archive.org/web/20140128101322/http://www.virtualmalaysia.com/tag/national-parks/ National Park in Malaysia] - Virtual Malaysia (Malaysia Social Travel Channel)
{{Malaysia topics}}
[[Category:Lists of national parks|Malaysia]] [[Category:Malaysia-related lists|N]] [[Category:National parks of Malaysia| ]] [[Category:Protected areas of Malaysia| ]] [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in Malaysia]]

page.title: List of nature centers in Illinois

revision.text:
<!-- Note: Please do not add websites for nature centers with existing Wikipedia articles. All websites should be listed on the main article. -->
This is a '''list of [[nature center]]s in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Illinois]]'''.
==Nature centers== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Name ! Location ! County ! Region ! Summary |- | [[Adams Wildlife Sanctuary]] || [[Springfield, Illinois|Springfield]] || [[Sangamon County, Illinois|Sangamon]] || [[Central Illinois|Central]] || 40 acres, operated by the Illinois Audubon Society |- | Andresen Nature Center || [[Fulton, Illinois|Fulton]] || [[Whiteside County, Illinois|Whiteside]] || [[Northwestern Illinois|Northwest]] || [https://www.cityoffulton.us/chamber/fulton-directory/attractions/andresen-nature-center.html information], operated by volunteers, open for city events and education programs, features displays of local wildlife, insects, and flora found along the local watershed of the upper Mississippi River |- | Anita Purves Nature Center || [[Urbana, Illinois|Urbana]] || [[Champaign County, Illinois|Champaign]] || Central || [http://www.urbanaparks.org/facilities/anita-purves-nature-center/ website], operated by Urbana Park District, exhibits on the natural history of Illinois, interactive and hands-on displays, live animals, located in Crystal Lake Park, adjacent to Busey Woods, a 59-acre forest preserve |- | Army Trail Nature Center || [[Addison, Illinois|Addison]] || [[DuPage County, Illinois|DuPage]] || [[Chicago metropolitan area|Chicago area]] || [http://www.asd4.org/docs/naturecenter.pdf website], 17 acres, outdoor classroom, partnership of the Addison Park District, Addison Elementary School District 4 & DuPage High School District 88 |- | Ballard Nature Center || [[Altamont, Illinois|Altamont]] || [[Effingham County, Illinois|Effingham]] || Central || [http://www.ballardnaturecenter.org/ website], 210 acre preserve |- | [[Henry N. Barkhausen Cache River Wetlands Center|Barkhausen Cache River Wetlands Center]] || [[Cypress, Illinois|Cypress]] || [[Johnson County, Illinois|Johnson]] || [[Southern Illinois|Southern]] || Exhibits about natural history of the [[Cache River Wetlands]] and [[Cypress Creek National Wildlife Refuge]], managed by the [[Illinois Department of Natural Resources]] |- | [[James "Pate" Philip State Park#Bartlett Nature Center|Bartlett Nature Center]] || [[Bartlett, Illinois|Bartlett]] || [[DuPage County, Illinois|DuPage]] || Chicago area || Located in the [[James "Pate" Philip State Park]], operated by the Bartlett Park District<ref>{{cite web|title=Nature Center|url=http://www.bartlettparkdistrict.com/naturecenter/|publisher=Bartlett Park District|accessdate=21 September 2012}}</ref> |- | [[Black Hawk State Historic Site]] ||[[Rock Island, Illinois|Rock Island]] || [[Rock Island County, Illinois|Rock Island]] || [[Northern Illinois|Northern]] || 208-acre park includes Singing Bird Nature Center for outdoor education programs and native bird section, and a museum of Native American life |- | Cabin Nature Center || [[Wood Dale, Illinois|Wood Dale]] || DuPage || Chicago area || [http://www.wooddaleparkdistrict.org/facilities/cabin-nature-center.aspx website], operated by the Wood Dale Park District |- | Creek Bend Nature Center || [[St. Charles, Illinois|St. Charles]] || [[Kane County, Illinois|Kane]] || Chicago area || [http://www.kaneforest.com/natureCenter.aspx website], operated by the Forest Preserve District of Kane County in 439-acre LeRoy Oakes Forest Preserve, interpretive displays including prairie ecology and Fox River |- | Crabtree Nature Center || [[Barrington, Illinois|Barrington]] || [[Cook County, Illinois|Cook]] || Chicago area || [http://fpdcc.com/nature-centers/crabtree-nature-center/ website], operated by the [[Forest Preserve District of Cook County]], over 1,000 acres, features outdoor nature play area |- | Crystal Lake Nature Center || [[Crystal Lake, Illinois|Crystal Lake]] || [[McHenry County, Illinois|McHenry]] || [[Northern Illinois|Northern]] || [http://www.crystallakeparks.org/Parks-Facilities/Nature-Center/general.asp website], operated by the Crystal Lake Park District in 130-acre Veterans Acres Park, seasonal butterfly house |- | [[Douglas-Hart Nature Center]] || [[Mattoon, Illinois|Mattoon]] || [[Coles County, Illinois|Coles]] ||Central || 70 acre preserve with prairie, woodlands and wetlands habitat, 2 miles of trails, interactive displays of local wild life, live reptiles and amphibians, a bird observation area, children's discovery den, library |- | Eden Place Nature Center || [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://www.edenplacenaturecenter.org/ website], 3-acre urban nature preserve with a focus on food production and environmental education |- | Emily Oaks Nature Center || [[Skokie, Illinois|Skokie]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://skokieparks.org/emily-oaks-nature-center website], 13 acres, operated by the Skokie Park District |- | Environmental Learning Center of Will County || [[Mokena, Illinois|Mokena]] || [[Will County, Illinois|Will]] || Chicago area || [http://www.reconnectwithnature.org/visitor-centers/elc website], operated by the [[Forest Preserve District of Will County]] |- | Forest Park Nature Center || [[Peoria, Illinois|Peoria]] || [[Peoria County, Illinois|Peoria]] || Central || [http://www.peoriaparks.org/forest-park-nature-center website], operated by the Peoria Park District, 540 acre preserve, 7 miles of trails, natural history museum and bird observation room, musical and educational programs |- | Four Rivers Environmental Education Center || [[Channahon, Illinois|Channahon]] || [[Will County, Illinois|Will]] || Chicago area || [http://www.reconnectwithnature.org/visitor-centers/freec website], operated by the [[Forest Preserve District of Will County]] in 525-acre McKinley Woods - Kerry Sheridan Grove |- | [[Forest Preserve District of DuPage County#Fullersburg Woods Nature Education Center|Fullersburg Woods Nature Education Center]] || [[Oak Brook, Illinois|Oak Brook]] || DuPage || Chicago area || Operated by the Forest Preserve District of DuPage County, 226 acres, exhibits on area natural history |- | [[Kennicott Grove|The Grove]] || [[Glenview, Cook County, Illinois|Glenview]] || Cook ||Chicago area || Operated by the Glenview Park District, 123 acres, natural and cultural history displays, 1856 period house, log cabin, Native American [[longhouse]], replica one-room schoolhouse, wetland greenhouse |- | Hawthorne Hill Nature Center || [[Elgin, Illinois|Elgin]] || [[Kane County, Illinois|Kane]] || Chicago area || [http://www.cityofelgin.org/index.aspx?NID=248 website], 67 acres, operated by the City |- | Heller Nature Center || [[Highland Park, Illinois|Highland Park]] || [[Lake County, Illinois|Lake]] || Chicago area || [http://www.pdhp.org/heller-nature-center/ website], operated by the City, 97 acre preserve with 3 miles of trails |- | Hidden Oaks Nature Center || [[Bolingbrook, Illinois|Bolingbrook]] || Will || Chicago area || [http://www.bolingbrookparks.org/Attractions_and_Facilities/Hidden_Oaks_Nature_Center/General_Information.aspx website], operated by the Bolingbrook Park District, almost 80 acres, hands-on discovery center, nature playground, outdoor amphitheater, Seedlings Nature Preschool |- | Kent Fuller Air Station Prairie/Tyner Center || [[Glenview, Cook County, Illinois|Glenview]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://glenviewparks.org/index.php/facilities-parks/kent-fuller-air-station-prairietyner-center/ website], operated by the Glenview Park District, 32-acre remnant of a tall-grass prairie, seasonal educational programs about the prairie, the environment and "green" programs |- | Kildeer Nature Center || [[Kildeer, Illinois|Kildeer]] || Lake || Chicago area|| [http://www.villageofkildeer.com/nature-center website], 5 acres of open space, operated by the Village |- | [[Ladd Arboretum|Ladd Arboretum & Evanston Ecology Center]] || [[Evanston, Illinois|Evanston]] || Cook || Chicago area || 23 acre arboretum and nature education facility |- | Lake Katherine Nature Center and Botanic Gardens || [[Palos Heights, Illinois|Palos Heights]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://www.lakekatherine.org/ website], operated by the City, 85-acre park, 20-acre man-made lake with gardens, woodlands, and prairie |- | [[Lake Renwick Preserve]] || [[Plainfield, Illinois|Plainfield]] || Will || Chicago area || Operated by the [[Forest Preserve District of Will County]], 320 acre site and 200 acre lake where great blue herons, great egrets, black-crowned night herons, double-crested cormorants, and cattle egrets nest together, features Lake Renwick Heron Rookery Visitor Center with birding programs |- | Lakeview Nature Center || [[Macomb, Illinois|Macomb]] || [[McDonough County, Illinois|McDonough]] || Central || [http://macombparkdistrict.com/lakeview-nature-center/ website], operated by the City, adjacent to [[Spring Lake Park (Illinois)|Spring Lake Park]], 55 acres of prairie, interactive displays and hands on programs that emphasize exploration and investigation of the environment |- | Laws of Nature Center || [[Yorkville, Illinois|Yorkville]] || [[Kendall County, Illinois|Kendall]] || Chicago area || [http://www.co.kendall.il.us/forest-preserve/laws-of-nature-center/ website], operated by the Kendall County Forest Preserve District, exhibits about prairies, insects, Native Americans, live bees, snakes, salamanders and frogs |- | [[Abraham Lincoln Memorial Garden|Lincoln Memorial Garden and Nature Center]] || [[Springfield, Illinois|Springfield]] || Sangamon || Central || 100-acre (0.4 km²) woodland and prairie garden owned by the city of Springfield and managed by the Abraham Lincoln Memorial Garden Foundation |- | Little Red Schoolhouse Nature Center || [[Willow Springs, Illinois|Willow Springs]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://fpdcc.com/nature-centers/little-red-schoolhouse-nature-center/ website], operated by the Forest Preserve District of Cook County, interactive exhibits, live animals |- | Lockhart Family Nature Center || [[Lake Forest, Illinois|Lake Forest]] || Lake || Chicago area || [http://www.lfola.org/mellody-farm-nature-preserve website], operated by Lake Forest Open Lands, located on 50-acre Mellody Farm Nature Preserve with the adjacent 514-acre Middlefork Savanna Forest Preserve |- | Lost Valley Visitor Center || [[Crystal Lake, Illinois|Crystal Lake]] || [[McHenry County, Illinois|McHenry]] || [[Northern Illinois|Northern]] || [http://www.mccdistrict.org/rccms/index.php/lost-valley-visitor-center/ website], operated by the McHenry County Conservation District in 3,200-acre Glacial Park |- | Lyman Woods Nature Center || [[Downers Grove, Illinois|Downers Grove]] || DuPage || Chicago area || [http://www.dgparks.org/places-to-go/nature-center website], operated by the village, 150 acres of oak woods, prairie, and marsh habitat, William F. Sherman, Jr. Interpretive Center features changing exhibits and activities, native landscaping, butterfly and [[rain garden]]s |- | [[Morton Arboretum]] || [[Lisle, Illinois|Lisle]] || DuPage|| Chicago area || 1,700 acres, offers extensive nature-entered education programs |- | Natural Resources Education Center at Russell Preserve || [[Genoa, Illinois|Genoa]] || [[DeKalb County, Illinois|DeKalb]] || Chicago area || [http://www.dekalbcounty.org/ForestPreserve/other.html website], operated by the DeKalb County Forest Preserve for environmental education programs |- | North Park Village Nature Center || [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://www.chicagoparkdistrict.com/facilities/nature-center/ website], forty-six acre nature preserve and an educational facility, operated by City |- | Peck Farm Park || [[Geneva, Illinois|Geneva]] || Kane || Chicago area || [http://www.genevaparks.org/facilities/pfic.html website], operated by the City, 385 acre park featuring a visitor's center with hands-on nature and history displays, observation silo, trails, sports facilities, outdoor education center |- | Pilcher Park Nature Center || [[Joliet, Illinois|Joliet]] || Will || Chicago area || [http://03a9ea1.netsolhost.com/jpdj/index.php/facilities/pilcher-park-nature-center website], operated by the City, over 640 acres |- | [[Goodenow Grove Nature Preserve|Plum Creek Nature Center]] || [[Beecher, Illinois|Beecher]] || Will || Chicago area || Operated by the [[Forest Preserve District of Will County]] in 891-acre Goodenow Grove Nature Preserve, natural playscape featuring a pollinator garden, rain garden, and interactive play elements |- | Prairie Grass Nature Museum || [[Round Lake, Illinois|Round Lake]] || Lake || Chicago area|| [http://www.roundlakeareaparkdistrict.org/programs-nature-museum.cfm website], operated by the village, features realistic habitats, live animals, nature activities and programs |- | Red Oak Nature Center || [[North Aurora, Illinois|North Aurora]] || Kane || Chicago area || [http://www.foxvalleyparkdistrict.org/facilities/red-oak-nature-center/ website], operated by the Fox Valley Park District, 40+ acres, hands-on displays, live animals, nature preschool, cave |- | River Trail Nature Center || [[Northbrook, Illinois|Northbrook]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://fpdcc.com/nature-centers/river-trail-nature-center/ website], operated by the Forest Preserve District of Cook County, live animals, nature programs |- | Rivershire Park and Nature Center || [[Lincolnshire, Illinois|Lincolnshire]] || Lake || Chicago area || [http://www.village.lincolnshire.il.us/departments-services/parks-and-paths/lincolnshire-parks/rivershire-park-and-nature-center website], operated by the village, 15 acres, outdoor education programs |- | [[Robert Allerton Park]] || [[Willow Branch Township, Piatt County, Illinois|Willow Branch]] || [[Piatt County, Illinois|Piatt]] || Central || 1,517-acre (614 ha) park, nature center and conference center |- | [[Rock Springs Conservation Area|Rock Springs Conservation Area & Nature Center]] || [[Decatur, Illinois|Decatur]] || [[Macon County, Illinois|Macon]] || Central || 1,300 acres, operated by the Macon County Conservation District, includes nature center museum, restored farmhouse, about nine miles of hiking trails, and a paved bike trail |- | Sagawau Environment Learning Center || [[Lemont, Illinois|Lemont]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://fpdcc.com/nature-centers/sagawau-environment-learning-center/ website], operated by the Forest Preserve District of Cook County, exhibits on geology, history, and habitat management |- | Sand Ridge Nature Center || [[South Holland, Illinois|South Holland]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://fpdcc.com/nature-centers/sand-ridge-nature-center/ website], operated by the Forest Preserve District of Cook County, 235 acres, exhibits on the natural and cultural history of the Calumet region, native animals, reproduction early 19th century log cabins |- | Severson Dells Nature Center ||[[Rockford, Illinois|Rockford]] || [[Winnebago County, Illinois|Winnebago]] || [[Northern Illinois|Northern]] || [http://seversondells.com website], operated by the County, 369-acre county forest preserve |- | Spring Brook Nature Center || [[Itasca, Illinois|Itasca]] || DuPage|| Chicago area || [http://www.itasca.com/index.aspx?NID=461 website], operated by the village, 2 miles of trails, aquarium, butterfly garden |- | Stillman Nature Center || [[South Barrington, Illinois|South Barrington]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://www.stillmannc.org/ website], private, non-profit center for environmental education located on 80 acres of woods, lake and prairie, live birds of prey |- | Stronghold Camp & Retreat Center || [[Oregon, Illinois|Oregon]] || [[Ogle County, Illinois|Ogle]] || [[Northern Illinois |Chicago area]] || [http://wwww.strongholdcenter.org/outdoored.html website], 360 acres, outdoor classroom, can host up to 180 people. |- | [[Funks Grove, Illinois#Sugar Grove Nature Center|Sugar Grove Nature Center]] || [[Funks Grove, Illinois|Funk's Grove]] || [[McLean County, Illinois|McLean]] || Central || Located within the 18-acre Funk's Grove Nature Preserve, interpretive environmental exhibits, sensory displays, live animals and a wildlife viewing area<ref>{{cite web|title=Nature Partners Program|url=http://www.sugargrovenaturecenter.org/naturepartners.htm|publisher=Sugar Grove Nature Center|accessdate=21 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005014724/http://www.sugargrovenaturecenter.org/naturepartners.htm|archivedate=5 October 2012|df=}}</ref> |- | [[Thorn Creek Nature Center and Preserve]] || [[Park Forest, Illinois|Park Forest]] || Will || Chicago area || Operated by the [[Forest Preserve District of Will County]], 985 acres, over 3 miles of trails |- | Trailside Museum of Natural History || [[River Forest, Illinois|River Forest]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://fpdcc.com/nature-centers/hal-tyrell-trailside-museum/ website], operated by the Forest Preserve District of Cook County, displays of live native animals, wildflower gardens, information about local wildlife and their habitats |- | Vera Meineke Nature Center at Spring Valley || [[Schaumburg, Illinois|Schaumburg]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://www.parkfun.com/spring-valley/nature-center website], operated by City, 135 acres, earth-sheltered, passive-solar visitor center, includes hands-on exhibits, discovery niches and a natural history library, park includes Volkening Heritage Farm, an 1880s living history farm |- | [[Volo Bog State Natural Area]] || [[Ingleside, Illinois|Ingleside]] || Lake || Chicago area || Over 1100 acres including a 45-acre bog, visitor center with exhibits, bog tours, prairie walks, insect and aqua safari's, summer bat programs and more |- | Watershed Nature Center || [[Edwardsville, Illinois|Edwardsville]] || [[Madison County, Illinois|Madison]] || [[Metro East]] || [http://www.watershednaturecenter.org/ website], owned by the City of Edwardsville, managed by the Nature Preserve Foundation, Inc., over 40 acres, 1 mile trail, restored prairie, wetlands and woods |- | Wildlife Discovery Center || [[Lake Forest, Illinois|Lake Forest]] || Lake || Chicago area || [http://www.cityoflakeforest.com/cs/rec/cs_rec2d2.htm website], operated by the City, located at 670-acre Elawa Farm, includes nature center, live animals, wildlife sanctuary, museum, and biological station |- | Wildwood Nature Center || [[Park Ridge, Illinois|Park Ridge]] || Cook || Chicago area || [http://www.parkridgeparkdistrict.com/facilities/wildwood-nature-center website], operated by Park Ridge Park District, 5 acres, live animals, nature exhibits |- | [[Willowbrook Wildlife Center]] || [[Glen Ellyn, Illinois|Glen Ellyn]] || DuPage || Chicago area || Operated by the [[Forest Preserve District of DuPage County]], native wildlife rehabilitation facility with rehabilitated animals on display, education, trails |- |}

page.title: List of rare flora of the Warren region

revision.text:
[[Image:Banksia brownii shrubby cropped.jpg|thumb|right|The endangered ''[[Banksia brownii]]'' (Feather-leaved Banksia) occurs in the Warren region.]] This is a '''list of endangered flora of the [[Warren (biogeographic region)|Warren]] region''', a [[biogeography|biogeographic]] region in southern [[Western Australia]]. It includes all taxa that occur in the region, and that have been classified as "R: Declared Rare Flora - Extant Taxa" or "X: Declared Rare Flora - Presumed Extinct Taxa" under the [[Department of Environment and Conservation (Western Australia)|Department of Environment and Conservation]]'s [[Declared Rare and Priority Flora List]], and are hence gazetted as endangered extant flora under the [[Wildlife Conservation Act 1950]].<ref name="Gazette">{{cite news | title = Wildlife Conservation (Rare Flora) Notice 2006(2) | url = http://www.naturebase.net/component/option,com_docman/task,doc_details/gid,403/Itemid,1208/ | format = PDF | work = [[Western Australian Government Gazette]] | publisher = [[Government of Western Australia]] | pages = 5311–5317 | date = 1 December 2006 | accessdate = 2007-01-17}}</ref>
There are 28 endangered taxa. ''[[Leucopogon cryptanthus]]'' is presumed extinct. The other 27 are believed extant:<ref name="Florabase">{{cite web | title = Florabase | url = http://florabase.calm.wa.gov.au | accessdate = 2007-01-31}}</ref> * [[Asplenium obtusatum subsp. northlandicum|''Asplenium obtusatum'' subsp. ''northlandicum'']] * ''[[Banksia brownii]]'' (Feather-leaved Banksia) * ''[[Banksia verticillata]]'' (Albany Banksia) * ''[[Boronia exilis]]'' * ''[[Brachyscias verecundus]]'' * ''[[Caladenia christineae]]'' * ''[[Caladenia excelsa]]'' * ''[[Caladenia harringtoniae]]'' * ''[[Caladenia winfieldii]]'' * ''[[Calectasia cyanea]]'' (Blue Tinsel Lily) * ''[[Darwinia ferricola]]'' ms * ''[[Diuris drummondii]]'' (Tall Donkey Orchid) * ''[[Drakaea micrantha]]'' * [[Dryandra nivea subsp. uliginosa|''Dryandra nivea'' subsp. ''uliginosa'']] * [[Epiblema grandiflorum var. cyaneum|''Epiblema grandiflorum'' var. ''cyaneum'']] ms (Blue Babe-in-a-cradle) * [[Grevillea brachystylis subsp. australis|''Grevillea brachystylis'' subsp. ''australis'']] * ''[[Hydatella dioica]]'' (Swan Hydatella) * ''[[Isopogon uncinatus ]]'' * ''[[Kennedia glabrata]]'' (Northcliffe Kennedia) * ''[[Kennedia macrophylla]]'' (Augusta Kennedia) * ''[[Lambertia orbifolia]]'' subsp. Scott River Plains * ''[[Meziella trifida]]'' * ''[[Microtis globula]]'' (South-coast Mignonette Orchid) * ''[[Reedia spathacea]]'' * ''[[Sphenotoma drummondii]]'' (Mountain Paper-heath) * [[Verticordia fimbrilepis subsp. australis|''Verticordia fimbrilepis'' subsp. ''australis'']] * [[Verticordia plumosa var. vassensis|''Verticordia plumosa'' var. ''vassensis'']]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rare flora of the Warren region}} [[Category:Rare flora of Australia| ]] [[Category:Lists of Australian plants]] [[Category:Flora of Western Australia|-]] [[Category:Conservation in Western Australia]] [[Category:Endemic flora of Australia]] [[Category:Lists of rare biota|Flora, Warren]] [[Category:Western Australia-related lists]]

revision.text:
[[Image:World ocean map.gif|right|thumb|250px|Animated map of the world's oceanic waters.]]
'''Marine Conservation Activism''' refers to the efforts of [[non-governmental organization]]s and individuals to bring about social and political change in the area of [[marine conservation]]. Marine conservation is properly conceived as a set of management strategies for the protection and preservation of [[ecosystem]]s in oceans and seas. Activists raise public awareness and support for conservation, while pushing governments and corporations to practice sound ocean management, create conservation policy, and enforce existing laws and policy through effective regulation. There are many different kinds of organizations and agencies that work toward these common goals. They all are a part of the growing movement that is ocean conservation. These organizations fight for many causes including stopping [[pollution]], [[overfishing]], [[whaling]], [[by-catch]]ing, and [[Marine Protected Area]]s.
==History== ===United States=== Though the [[environmental movement]] began in the United States during the 1960s, the idea of marine conservation really did not take off in the country until the 1972 [[Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act]] (MPRSA) passed, beginning the movement. The act allowed the regulation by the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) over dumping in the seas. Though the act was later amended, it was one of several key events to bring marine issues towards the front of environmental issues in the United States.
=== Notable People === * [[Jacques Cousteau]]: Explorer, Conservationist, Researcher & Author * [[Sylvia Earle]]: Marine Biologist, Explorer, & Author * [[Steve Irwin]]: Naturalist, Conservationist, Zoologist, Herpetologist, & Television Personality
==International Issues== ===Debris=== {{main|Marine debris}} [[Image:Marine debris on Hawaiian coast.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Marine debris]] on the [[Hawaii]]an coast]] Marine Debris is defined as “any persistent solid material that is manufactured or processed and directly or indirectly, intentionally or unintentionally, disposed of or abandoned into the marine environment or the Great Lakes”. This debris can injure or even kill marine organisms; it can also interfere with navigation safety and could pose a threat to human health. Marine debris can range from soda cans to plastic bags and can even include abandoned vessels or neglected fishing gear.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/marinedebris.html|title=What is marine debris?|last=Administration|first=US Department of Commerce, National Oceanic and Atmospheric|website=oceanservice.noaa.gov|language=EN-US|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref>
==== Ocean Conservancy ==== [[The Ocean Conservancy|Ocean Conservancy]] is a non-profit environmental group that fights for the improvement and conservation of marine ecosystems and marine life. They work to find science-based solutions to protect the world's oceans from the global challenges that they face today.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oceanconservancy.org/who-we-are/our-work.html|title=Ocean Conservancy: What We Do|website=www.oceanconservancy.org|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref>
One of the many issues that they work closely to stop is the flow of trash that enters the ocean. The International Coastal Cleanup (ICC) is one of the methods Ocean Conservancy uses to prevent marine debris. The ICC is the largest volunteer effort to clean up the world's oceans and other waterways; over the past 25 years the ICC has cleaned up approximately 144,606,491 pounds of trash from beaches all over the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oceanconservancy.org/our-work/marine-debris/|title=Ocean Conservancy: Fighting for Trash Free Seas|website=www.oceanconservancy.org|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref>
===Whaling=== {{main|Whaling}} {{see also|Anti-whaling}} {{see also|Unsure-about-whaling}}
[[Image:Whaling in the Faroe Islands.jpg|300px|thumb|Whaling in the [[Faroe Islands]].]]
==== International Whaling Commission ==== [[Whaling]] is the hunting of free roaming [[whale]]s; many whaling practices have led to drastic population loss in many whale populations around the world.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://us.whales.org/wdc-in-action/stop-whaling|title=Stop Whaling|newspaper=WDC, Whale and Dolphin Conservation|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> In 1986, The International Whaling Commission (IWC) was founded to put a ban on commercial whaling. The commission recognizes three different types of whaling: aboriginal subsistence, commercial, and special permit (or scientific) whaling.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://iwc.int/whaling|title=Whaling|website=iwc.int|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref>
===== Aboriginal Subsistence Whaling ===== This form of whaling supports indigenous communities where whale products play an important role in cultural and nutritional life. The IWC sets catch limits for aboriginal subsistence whaling every six years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://iwc.int/aboriginal|title=Aboriginal Subsistence Whaling in the Arctic|website=iwc.int|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref>
===== Commercial Whaling ===== This form of whaling is highly regulated by the IWC and is currently on a moratorium. There are a few countries that oppose the moratorium and continue to hunt for whales; these countries share catch data with the Commission but are not regulated by it.<ref name=":2" />
Since the moratorium was put in place in 1986, more than 50,000 whales have been hunted and killed; there are three nations that are still able to hunt whales because of loopholes in the ban. Norway is able to hunt because of an “objection” to the ban; Iceland is able to hunt because of a “reservation” and Japan is able to hunt because they claim it is for “research purposes”. If combined these nations kill around 2,000 whales each year; these whales include humpback, minke, sperm, fin, Bryde’s, and sei. The IWC ban does allow for some Aboriginal Subsistence Whaling (ASW) in certain countries.<ref name=":1" />
===== Special Permit/Scientific Whaling ===== This category of whaling is separated from IWC-regulated whaling by international law. Special permit research proposals are to be submitted by countries to the IWC for scientific scrutiny. The role of the IWC is advisory only.<ref name=":2" />
==== Greenpeace ==== [[Greenpeace]], an international environmental organization founded in 1971 in British Columbia, fights against whaling. Their campaigns are nonviolent and many times involve one or more of the five Greenpeace ships which first made the organization famous in the 1970s. In late December 2005, Japanese whaling fleets experienced heavy opposition from Greenpeace, who protested that the Japanese were continuing their commercial whaling under the guise of research,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article3325580.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=Australia condemns bloody killing of whale and calf by Japanese fleet | first=Paul | last=Larter | date=February 8, 2008 | accessdate=May 12, 2010}}</ref> and even worse, they were doing so in the [[Southern Ocean Whale Sanctuary]]. They sent volunteer workers in inflatable boats to get in the line of fire in order to stop the whaling.<ref name="SAVE">Michael McCarthy, "SAVE THE WHALE: 20 years on and whales are under threat again", ''The Independent (London)'', January 2, 2006, sec. A</ref>
==== Sea Shepherd Conservation Society ==== [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society]] is a non-profit, marine wildlife conservation organization that works internationally on numerous campaigns to protect the world’s oceans. Their mission is to conserve and protect the world’s ecosystems and species; they work to end the destruction of habitat and slaughter of the ocean’s wildlife. Unlike many other non-profit environmental groups, Sea Shepherd uses direct-action tactics to expose and challenge illegal activities at sea; they strive to ensure that the ocean can survive for future generations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.seashepherd.org/who-we-are/ |title=Who We Are - Sea Shepherd Conservation Society |newspaper=Sea Shepherd Conservation Society |language=en-US |access-date=2016-11-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830114857/http://www.seashepherd.org/who-we-are/ |archivedate=2009-08-30 |df= }}</ref> In doing so, they refer to the [[United Nations]] [[World Charter for Nature]] that calls on individuals to "safeguard and conserve nature in areas beyond national jurisdiction".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.seashepherd.org/who-we-are/mandate.html|title=Mandate - Sea Shepherd Conservation Society|newspaper=Sea Shepherd Conservation Society|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-14}}</ref>
Sea Shepherd was founded in 1977 by [[Paul Watson|Captain Paul Watson]] in [[Vancouver]] BC, Canada; it wasn’t until 1981 that it was formally incorporated in the United States. Throughout the years their campaigns have ranged from stopping the annual killing of baby harp seals in Eastern Canada to preventing Japanese whalers from killing endangered whale species.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.seashepherd.org/who-we-are/our-history.html|title=Our History - Sea Shepherd Conservation Society|newspaper=Sea Shepherd Conservation Society|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129025542/http://www.seashepherd.org/who-we-are/our-history.html|archive-date=2016-11-29|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> They only work to uphold international conservation law and to protect the endangered ocean habitats and species; they do this without prejudice against race, nationality, color, or religious belief. Their crews are made up of volunteers from all over the world, some of which are from countries that Sea Shepherd has campaigns against; they describe themselves as “pro-ocean” instead of “anti-any nationality or culture”.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.seashepherd.org/who-we-are/equality-statement.html|title=Equality Statement - Sea Shepherd Conservation Society|newspaper=Sea Shepherd Conservation Society|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-14}}</ref>
=== Shark Finning === <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:130104081845-hong-kong-roof-shark-fins-horizontal-large-gallery.jpg|thumb| About half of the world’s trade in fins currently happens in Hong Kong. ]] --> {{main article|Shark finning}} {{see also|Shark fin soup}} [[Shark finning]] is a worldwide issue that involves cutting off the fins of [[shark]]s. This is done while the shark is still alive followed by the rest of the body being thrown back into the ocean, leaving it to die days after.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.stopsharkfinning.net/|title=Stop Shark Finning|website=Stop Shark Finning|access-date=2016-11-14}}</ref> Used in countries like China and Japan, shark fins are a key ingredient in the world-renowned meal, [[shark fin soup]]. The high demand for this particular type of soup has skyrocketed in the last few decades and sells for around $100 on average and is often catered at special occasions such as weddings and banquets. Due to the increased want for these shark fins, traders seek out the fins in order to make a profit. However, the fins are the only part of the shark that fishermen seek out to retrieve due to the low economical value of the actual shark meet.<ref name=":0" /> This recently exposed issue along with other overfishing issues has brought upon roughly 80 percent of the shark population decline. It has become prominent concern in marine conservation activism for millions of sharks are killed yearly at an often-unregulated expense.
==== Project AWARE ==== Current campaign known as [[Project AWARE]] is working globally to advocate solutions for long-term protection for these animals. Created initially as an environmental initiative project, this campaign was developed by the Professional Associations of Diving Instructors (PADI) in 1989. Used to educate divers about environmental problems this program eventually grew to become a registered non-profit organization in the US in 1992 and eventually became recognized in the UK and Australia in 1999 and 2002 respectively. In spite of the arising issues with marine challenges, Project AWARE has continued to grow towards meeting the needs of the marine ecosystem as they see fit. Marine debris and shark and ray conservation activism are the two most prevalent issues that are being further worked toward improving since 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.projectaware.org/sharks?gclid=Cj0KEQjwnKzABRDy2pb7nPSazdsBEiQAI4lZQMf-1t5WI1DOO7SmK8CCRHnH_nNn1txHHprRZT43C-caAmLJ8P8HAQ|title=Sharks and Rays {{!}} Project AWARE|website=www.projectaware.org|access-date=2016-11-14}}</ref>
==== Shark Savers ==== Another huge campaign working to ensure the protection of these marine species is a group called Shark Savers that is sponsored by the group called [[WildAid]]. Through the use of community motivation, the project encourages the public to stop eating sharks and shark fin soup. By also working to improve global regulations and creating sanctuaries for sharks, the project aims to take action and get results. Similarly to Project Aware, the Shark Savers program was founded by a group of divers that wanted to help the marine system in 2007. Through the recent creation of shark sanctuaries, the program focuses on sustainability when thinking about the economical and environmental benefits. These created sanctuaries provide a protected area for the sharks and also promote change in nearby communities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sharksavers.org/en/home/|title=Shark Savers :: Home|website=www.sharksavers.org|access-date=2016-11-14}}</ref>
==== Bite-Back ==== [[Bite-Back]] is another organization that is active in the community and aims to stop the sale of shark fins for the making of shark fin soup in Great Britain. By exposing the UK and their acts toward profiting from shark products, they aim to put an end to their ways of over fishing and exploitation. The organizations main goal is to allow marine life a chance to thrive while they are busy doing the dirty work of lowering consumer stipulation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bite-back.com/about/|title=About - Bite-Back|website=www.bite-back.com|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref>
==== Shark Trust ==== Part of a worldwide alliance called The Global Shark and Ray Initiative (GSRI), the Shark Trust is working in efforts to better the ocean for marine animals such as shark and rays. The Initiative created a plan for changing the status of the shark population that would span over 10 years starting on February 15, 2016. Teaming up with other large conservation organization such as Shark Advocates International and [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] (WWF), the team aims to ultimately give these vulnerable animals the safety and security that the ought to have in their natural environment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sharktrust.org/en/global_strategy|title=The Shark Trust - Global Strategy|website=www.sharktrust.org|access-date=2016-12-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220074640/http://www.sharktrust.org/en/global_strategy|archive-date=2016-12-20|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
=== Overfishing === {{main article|Overfishing}} Overfishing occurs when fish stocks are over-exploited to below acceptable levels; eventually the fish populations will no longer be able to sustain themselves. This can lead to resource depletion, reduced biological growth, and low biomass levels.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120920-are-we-running-out-of-fish|title=How the world’s oceans could be running out of fish|last=Vince|first=Gaia|access-date=2016-12-07}}</ref>
==== Global Fishing Watch ==== In September 2016, a partnership of Google and [[Oceana (non-profit group)|Oceana]] and Skytruth introduced [[Global Fishing Watch]], a website designed to assist citizens of the globe in monitoring fishing activities.<ref>[http://www.digitaltrends.com/web/global-fishing-watch-google/ Google Launches Global Fishing Watch]—''[[Digital Trends]]'' (September 16, 2016)</ref><ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/andrew-sharpless/oceana-unveils-global-fis_b_12030462.html Oceana Unveils Global Fishing Watch]—''[[Huffington Post]]'' (September 15, 2016)</ref><ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-09-16/illegal-fishing-watch-site-crowdsourced-solution-overfishing/7851064 Illegal fishing targeted by crowdsourcing thanks to new Global Fishing Watch website]—[[ABC News (Australia)|''ABC News'' (Australia)]] (September 15, 2016)</ref>
== Solutions == ===Marine protected areas=== {{main|Marine protected area}}
Even though the idea of Marine Protected Areas is an internationally known concept, there is no one term used internationally. Rather, each country has its own name for the areas. [[Marine reserve|Marine Reserves]], Specially Protected Areas, Marine Park all relate to this concept, though differ slightly. Some of the most famous Marine Protected Areas are the [[Ligurian Sea Cetacean Sanctuary]] along the coasts of Spain, Monaco, and Italy, and Australia's [[Great Barrier Reef]]. The largest sanctuary in the world is the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands National Monument. The purpose of these sanctuaries is to provide protection for the living and non- living resources of the oceans and seas. They are created to save species, nursing resources and to help sustain the fish population.
The activists at the [[Ocean Conservancy]] fight for this cause. They believe that the United States should put forth a consistent and firm commitment in using Marine Protected Areas as a management strategy. Currently, the argument in the United States is whether or not they are necessary, when it should be how can they work the most efficiently.<ref>David White, "Fully Protected Marine Reserves Will Promote Sustainable Fishing", 2001</ref> Activists at the Ocean Conservancy have been working on a campaign called the ''Save Our Ocean Legacy,'' a campaign lasting several years trying to establish Marine Protected Areas' off of the California coasts. 29 Marine Protected Areas were planned to be established when the legislation bill passed in 1999. The hope is that the plan will be finalized in 2007.<ref>Environment California, "Save Our Ocean Legacy,"{{cite web|url=http://www.environmentcalifornia.org/ocean-legacy/save-our-ocean-legacy |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070418122217/http://www.environmentcalifornia.org/ocean-legacy/save-our-ocean-legacy |archivedate=2007-04-18 |df= }}</ref>
Some fishers do not accept that Marine Protected Areas (MPA) benefit fish stocks and provide insurance against stock collapse. MPAs can cause a short-term loss in fisheries production.<ref>Robert L. Ship, "No Take Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) as a Fishery Management Tool, a Pragmatic Perspective: A Report to the FishAmerica Foundation", May 23, 2002</ref> However, the concept of spillover, where fish within a Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) move into fished areas, thus benefiting fisheries, has been misunderstood by some fishers.<ref>Richard B. Allen, "No-Take Reserves as a Fishery Management Tool", speech delivered at Fisheries, Oceanography, and Society: A Symposium Presented by the Ocean Life Institute, August 27, 2001</ref> The term is a simplification of numerous ecological benefits that are derived from removing fishing from nursery, breeding grounds and essential fish habitats.<ref>for example see N.A.J. Graham, R.D. Evans And G.R. Russ. 2003. The effects of marine reserve protection on the trophic relationships of reef fishes on the Great Barrier Reef. Environmental Conservation 30 (2): 200–208; Berkeley, S.A., Chapman, C., and Sogard, S. 2004. Maternal age as a determinant of larval growth and survival in a marine fish, Sebastes melanops. Ecology 85(5):1258-1264. http://californiafish.org/maternal_age.pdf; Longhurst, A. 2002. Murphy's Law revisited: longevity as a factor in recruitment to fish populations. Fisheries Research 56:125-131. http://www.cnr.uidaho.edu/fish510/PDF/Longhurst.pdf;Walsh{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, M.R., Munch, S.B., Chiba, S., and Conover, D.O. 2006. Maladaptive changes in multiple traits caused by fishing: impediments to population recovery". Ecology Letters 9:142-148. http://www.msrc.sunysb.edu/people/munchpdf/Walsh_et_al06_EcolLet.pdf</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{aquatic ecosystem topics|expanded=marine}} {{fishery science topics|expanded=none}}
